advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://uratomo.hp.infoseek.co.jp/game/museum/msx/f1xd.htm" target="_blank">Dreaming Tomorrow</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Imagine a microcomputer with all the design savvy, ruggedness, and sophistication of the best minicomputers.<br> Imagine a microcomputer supported by dozens of interface, memory and processor option boards. One that can be Interfaced to an indefinite number of peripheral devices including dual floppy discs, CRTs, line printers, cassette recorders, video displays, paper tape readers, teleprinters. plotters, and custom devices.<br> Imagine a microcomputer supported by extensive software IncludIng Extended BASIC, DISK BASIC, DOS and a complete library of business, developmental, and Industrial programs.<br> ImagIne a microcomputer that will do everything a mini will do, only at a fraction of the cost.<br> You are imagining the Altair 8800b. The Altair 8800b is here today, and it may very welt be the mainframe of the 70's. <br><br> The Altair 8800b is a second generation design of the most popular microcomputer In the field, the Altair 8800. Built around the 8800A microprocessor, the Altair 8800b is an open ended machine that is compatible with all Altair 8800 hardware and software. It can be configured to match most any system need.<br> MITS' plug-In compatible boards for the Altair 8800b now include: 4K static memory. 4K dynamic memory, 16K static memory, multi-port serial interface, multi-port parallel interface, audio cassette record interface, vectored interrupt, real time clock, PROM board, multiplexer, AID convertor, extender card, disc controller and line printer interface.<br> MITS' peripherals for the Altair 8800b include the Altair Floppy Disc, Altair Line Printer, teletypewriters, and the soon-to-be-announced Altair CRT terminal. <br><br> Introductory prices for the Altair 8800b are $840 for a kit with complete assembly instructions, and $1100 for an assembled unit. Complete documentation, membership into the Altair Users Club, subscription to "Computer Notes", access to the Altair Software Library, and a copy of Charles J. Sippi's Microcomputer Dictionary are included.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing is very simple with the AIM65 from Rockwell"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IEEE INTERFACE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The Acorn IEEE interface enables full implementation of the IEEE standard 488-1978. IEEE488 is also known, and is equivalent to IEC625-1 (in Europe), and GPIB or HP-IB (Hewlett Packard General Purpose Interface Bus)...<br> ...The interface can support a network of up to 14 other IEEE-488 compatible devices. Devices can be interconnected in a star or linear fashion. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a part of a complete French price list of the C64 and VIC-20, including peripherals, accessories and software.<br> You can download the <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/Museum/downloads/Commodore/FrPriceList.zip">complete version</a>.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This November 1982 advert introduces the new CoCo 1 price : $299 instead of $399.<br><br> Even if the advert said:<br><font color="#666666">"Hurry - this fantastic offer ends december 31, 1982" </font><br>the price never came back to $399.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (AUG. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Happy family playing "La quête des anneaux" (Quest for the rings)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> CORTEX has been designed not to dominate your desk, to leave room for your calendar, your telephone, your in-tray and the rest. If you want it inconspicuous, buy iy in conventional cream. But for extroverts, and the fashion conscious, CORTEX comes in bright, bright colours - warm red, C/WP green, sunshine yellow, ice white and all black...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SAME WITH A MAN</strong></font><br><blockquote>Less impressive...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert for Instructor 50, Byte March 1979, Page 45.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Adam Trinfo for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>1982 - Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Stop in a store near you. Take a look. You'll be instantly taken with some of the features that make the IBM Personal Computer so different...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Kaypro, it runs" ! <br><br> "Kaypro, the computer which can be carried away" <br><br> "Elected Transportable Computer of the year"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY 1988 CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.switchtech.us/Tandy1000.html" target="_blank">SWITCHTECH'S Tandy 1000SX page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
In the late 70s Siemens licencied the Intel 8080 processor and became a 8080 chip second source European manufacturer.
After having translated the 8080 user's manual to German, they marketed the SME development system ( Siemens Microcomputer Entwicklungssystem) which was the same system as the Intel Intellec Series 2 MDS (Microcomputer Development System). The system had a 8080 processor in its first version, later an Intel P8080A-2 (an increased-speed 8080), then finally a 4 MHz. 8085.
For the major part, the SME was made by Intel in USA. The only difference between Intel and Siemens systems was the cabinet colour: grey for Siemens's, blue for Intel's. The SME system was very popular with german 8080 /8085 hardware and firmware developers.
Thanks to Gottfried Silberhorn from Germany for information and pictures.
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke 62 keys managed by an Intel 8741 processor
computer.name: SME

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>DB25 connectors, from top to bottom:<br><br> - Serial port 1<br> - Serial port 2<br> - Paper tape puncher<br> - Paper tape reader<br> - Parallel printer<br> - Eprom programmer<br><br> Left connector and cable go to the keyboard. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> RAM memory chips area<br> <b>(2)</b> 8202 RAM controller chip<br> <b>(3)</b> 8219 bus controller chip<br> <b>(4)</b> EPROM chip holding the monitor program<br> <b>(5)</b> 8085 processor<br> <b>(6)</b> 8259 Programmable interrupt controller chips<br> <b>(7)</b> 8251 Programmable communication interface (USART) chips<br> <b>(8)</b> 8253 Programmable Interval Timer chip<br> <b>(9)</b> Data switches and leds. </blockquote>
